item.title: Dragon Age: The Veilguard - How To Solve Forest Mire & Waterfront Glades Beam Generator Puzzle
item.description:
There are various puzzles players might stumble upon while exploring the regions in Dragon Age: The Veilguard . Some puzzles are complicated, like the Warden Vault one, while others are extremely easy and unlock a small room full of loot.

Upon reaching a certain clearing in the Arlathan Forest, Rook will notice a big chest on a small patch of land in the middle of the lake. There is no way to reach it, but a couple of beam generators are lying around that you can use to solve the puzzle.

How To Solve Forest Mire Beam Generator Puzzle In Dragon Age: The Veilguard

To reach the location, fast travel to the Beacon northeast of the Veil Jumpers camp, spawning Rook in the Ancient Aqueduct. Head east and climb the ladder, then proceed east inside the destroyed building to reach Forest Mire, the puzzle location. The island in the middle is surrounded by water.

To solve the Forest Mire and Waterfront Glades Beam Generator puzzle , players must locate three beam generators and aim them at faraway Energy Nodes to create a pathway to the unreachable land.

Beam Generator Location #1

From the Forest Mire’s entrance, head east across the fallen tree log and use Harding to move a rock and climb a higher hill. Summon Lace’s powers and push two stones out to cross the river safely. A beam generator can be seen, but it’s deactivated.

Jump to the lower ground behind it to the north to find a working generator. Aim at the Energy Node beneath the higher generator to activate it, then aim it at the faraway Energy Node on the island.

Beam Generator Location #2

Jump down again from the previous location, and go northwest to stumble upon a turned-off beam generator behind some bushes. Go to the nearby statue to find a Power Crystal around the crates. Grab it to activate the beam generator and aim it at the island's Energy Node.

Beam Generator Location #3

Turn around, climb the stairs, then run left towards the fallen tree log. Approach the short gate, and open it to see a blue barrier across. Take the Power Crystal to remove the barrier and place it on the Energy Node next to the beam generator. Finally, aim it at a faraway Node.

A bridge will magically appear, leading to the patch of land in the middle of the lake. However, be careful as a level 26 Guardian of Secrets boss is guarding the chest in Dragon Age: The Veilguard . Once you defeat it, open the chest to get a Unique Light Helm, the Iron Veil.

item.title: 7 RPGs With Great Enemy Chatter
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Cyberpunk 2077 offers intense enemy chatter during shootouts.
  • Dark Souls 3 stands out with epic boss dialogues during fights.
  • The Witcher 3 features engaging dialogues with key antagonists.

While other genres in gaming offer players amazing experiences, few can match the vastness and versatility of RPG s. In most cases, this genre not only presents players with the opportunity to create and customize their own character, but also recruit party members, upgrade their stats to their liking and explore worlds full of life and side quests.

Combat, narrative, the variety of weapons and companions available, as well as the quality of the missions are very important in a game. But what really makes an RPG stand out is how intimidating or interesting enemy chatter is, whether it comes from a regular enemy or a powerful boss. Here are some of the best RPGs with great enemy chatter.

7 Cyberpunk 2077

Clearing An Area Of Enemies Usually Comes With Some Great Dialogue

  • Large variety of weapons, vehicles and missions
  • Enemy chatter is present in every shootout

When it comes to dystopian futuristic societies with tons of enemies to face, few games pull the concept off, as well as Cyberpunk 2077 . Not only does this title feature some amazing Cyberware upgrades for players to improve their combat skills, but there are also tons of high-speed vehicles to drive, and different enemies to defeat.

As players progress through the story, they will encounter certain areas that they'll have to clear out either to progress through a specific mission or to help the NCPD in exchange for a few rewards. In any case, they'll be faced with constant enemy chatter that will only cease when every hostile has been flatlined.

6 Dark Souls 3

Bosses Have The Most Epic Opening Statements

  • Area enemies are usually silent
  • Many bosses have great dialogues and interesting chatter as players fight them

Dark Souls 3 and other FromSoftware games are known for their considerable difficulty level, the bleak world they're set in, and the large variety of nightmarish enemies and bosses that players can encounter along the way. However, one aspect of these titles that few players talk about, but almost everyone loves, is the boss chatter.

Although most area enemies are silent and restrict themselves only to grunting or maniacal laughters, bosses typically have an opening cutscene, where they take advantage of their time in the spotlight to drop some of the coldest lines in their universe. Additionally, some bosses also keep talking as players fight them, making the experience even more epic.

5 The Witcher 3

Guards, Thieves, And Some Main Antagonists Have A Lot To Say

  • A masterpiece that still holds up very well
  • Antagonists like Gaunter O'Dimm have amazing, interactive dialogues

The Witcher 3 is one of those games that players know will be a timeless classic in a decade or so, as it's already beloved by millions and the franchise has inspired TV shows, collectibles, and tons of fan tributes. Even though the game was released almost 10 years ago at the time of writing this article, its RPG game mechanics still feel fresh, allowing it to compete and even overshadow many modern titles in the genre.

Fighting enemies like guards is fun and makes for a few great lines during combat. However, where this game's enemy chatter truly shines is around entities like Gaunter O'Dimm, the main antagonist of the Hearts of Stone DLC. Not only is this character the closest thing to the devil in The Witcher universe, but he also has very interesting dialogue that players can interact with. The game also has optional quests with a few enemies with outstanding dialogue, so there's no shortage of options when it comes to conversation.

4 Star Wars: Knights Of The Old Republic

Darth Malak's Ruthlessness Can Be Sensed In His Words

  • A timeless classic that is still played and beloved today by many
  • Darth Malak and Saul Karath have great dialogues

When it comes to the best Star Wars games, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic is arguably at the top of the list. While this game was released more than 20 years ago and pales in comparison to most modern titles in terms of graphics, character animations and game mechanics, it remains a masterpiece in the RPG genre.

Similar to the Dark Souls franchise, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic restricts its area enemies to grunts and repetitive death sounds during combat. However, characters like Darth Malak and Admiral Saul Karath have very interesting things to say throughout the game, greatly elevating the narrative.

3 The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim

Enemy Chatter Can Be A Little Repetitive, But It's Also Great

  • Great variety of weapons, armor, and enemies
  • Enemy phrases are a bit repetitive, but are also part of what makes Skyrim great

While The Elder Scrolls franchise has tons of great installments, The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim is arguably the most complex and fun to play of them all. With tons of weapons, armor, and enemy variety, as well as several mods that can change the experience significantly, this title is still played and beloved by many, nearly a decade and a half after its initial release.

Granted, enemy chatter in Skyrim can get a little repetitive, but it's so iconic, that it's also a classic. Phrases like "never should have come here" are ingrained in most players' brains and are often used on internet forums and pop-culture references.

2 Baldur's Gate 3

Enemy Chatter Works Well With The Narrative, Making The Experience More Immersive

  • A complex and complete RPG that can entertain players for hours on end
  • Key antagonists have great chatter

Baldur's Gate 3 is probably the most influential, complex and complete RPG of the last five years, as it offers players the opportunity to explore vast fantastic worlds, develop relationships with interesting companions, and hone their skills and equipment to face the challenges on their path. Like other games on this list, Baldur's Gate 3' s enemy chatter truly shines when facing key antagonists in the story, like General Ketheric Thorm.

The game's narrative is already rich and complex without having outstanding enemy chatter, so the fact that that's also present, elevates the experience to a whole new level and explains why this title won Game of the Year in 2023.

1 Elden Ring

Some Bosses Speak From Pain And Suffering

  • The Lands Between are a vast, challenging open world
  • Bosses have epic dialogue throughout the various stages of their fights

Lastly, there's Elden Ring . This title not only revolutionized the concept of FromSoftware games, but also presented players with a vast open world that they could explore in detail. Sharing the difficulty level of a few other Soulsbornes, Elden Ring puts players to the test constantly—especially when facing bosses.

Just as it happens in the Dark Souls franchise, area enemies are rather quiet, so it's up to bosses to make up for all that silence, and for the most part, they absolutely deliver. While some bosses are also silent, those who speak before a fight, during combat, when they reach their second phase, or even after being defeated or killing the Tarnished, drop some of the best lines in gaming history.

item.title: Dragon Age: The Veilguard - The Plight Of The Veil Jumpers Walkthrough
item.description:
The Plight of the Veil Jumpers is one of the many side quests in Dragon Age: The Veilguard that cannot be accessed until you complete a prerequisite. In this case, players must have Davrin available as their companion as the quest area is discovered by completing his companion quest.

Rook can expect to trigger the Plight of the Veil Jumpers quest in Dragon Age: The Veilguard upon reaching the end of Act 1. The quest will later on appear as an exclamation mark on the Arlathan Forest map, waiting for players to trigger it.

How To Trigger The Plight Of The Veil Jumpers In Dragon Age: The Veilguard

After progressing through the main quests in Dragon Age: The Veilguard , you will eventually unlock Davrin as a companion. Complete Davrin’s first companion quest, How to Train a Griffon, and then head back to Arlathan Forest to find the Plight of the Veil Jumpers quest available. Speak with Elio, who tells you some Veil Jumpers went too long and haven’t returned.

Head to the marked location located northeast of the Veil Jumpers’ camp. Proceed deeper inside the forest to find a couple of portals and no sign of any Veil Jumpers. One will call you, but the path is blocked. To reach them, Rook must disable the relic causing the disruption.

Veil Jumper Location #1

Turn east and use the tree log to reach the other side. Call for Harding’s power to lift the rock and use it as leverage to reach the higher hill. Deactivate the relic to remove all the portals, then head back to speak with the Veil Jumper.

Try not to approach any of the portals as they will transport you to another part of the forest.

Veil Jumper Location #2

From the previous location, proceed east to reach a blocked cave with a pile of sand in front of it. Call for Assan to dig up the relic, which causes an explosion upon approaching it. Head inside the cave to find the second Veil Jumper dead.

Veil Jumper Location #3

Go north while following the blue quest mark until a stair with floating rocks arch appears to the left. Continue north and climb the set of stairs to see an area blocked by a blue barrier. Ask Bellara to fix the relic, which creates a barrier and sends a horde of enemies towards you. Fight them, destroy the relic, and speak with the Veil Jumper.

Veil Jumper Location #4

Proceed west from the precious location to reach a big arch. Climb the nearby rocks and head north while activating all the exploding traps. Finally, you will reach the clearing where Davrin’s companion quest ended. Look up and deactivate the relic on the arch to open the barrier. Speak with the Veil Jumper, then return to Elio to receive your rewards.

item.title: Mario and Luigi: Brothership - All Rumbla Island Sprite Bulb Locations
item.description:
Quick Links

  • Where To Find Every Rumbla Island Sprite Bulb In Mario and Luigi: Brothership
  • What Are Sprite Bulbs Used For In Mario and Luigi: Brothership

Sprite Bulbs are a collectible item that usually appears on an island on your first visit, with more appearing on a revisit to further incentivize players to fast travel between islands, even after finishing the story there in Mario and Luigi: Brothership .

While the use of Sprite Bulbs isn't immediately known, it's best to start collecting them early on. Rumbla Island is the first one in the game, and after revisiting it for the first time, you'll be able to track down all the Sprite Bulbs on the island; here's where to find them.

Where To Find Every Rumbla Island Sprite Bulb In Mario and Luigi: Brothership

In total there are 28 Sprite Bulbs to be found on the island , spread out between 11 locations. After interacting with a Sprite Bulb and releasing them, they will run around and you'll simply need to catch up to them and make contact to collect them. Using Luigi Logic by pressing L will have him act independently and make catching each Bulb much easier.

You'll also need to get the hammers before you can reach every Sprite Bulb .

The first two bulbs are found right near the blue pipe when you enter the island. Along the far right side of the peninsula will be one set in the bottom right, and one roughly straight across to the left of the blue pipe.

The third Sprite Bulb location will be straight north from where you entered the island along the left side of the path. There will then be two more Sprite Bulbs if you continue left across the flower.

The seventh Sprite Bulb is found far to the right side of the island from the previous few. While the location of the Bulb is further north, head towards the flower along the bottom right side of the map and use it to jump on onto the hill. Heading north, you'll find panels that each brother will need to jump on in order based on the color and letter of the panel. On the far side will be another hill with a rock that can be smashed to reveal the Sprite Bulb.

The eighth Sprite Bulb location is found upon reaching town and heading left. Near the save block, you'll see a green L button that Luigi can press by hitting with his hammer to lower the bridge, with the Bulb being on the other side.

From the previous location, head to the far right side of the island to find the ninth Sprite Bulb location.

Heading further into the island and to the new eastern section now opened on your revisit, head to the middle section and down the hill to the yellow rock. Destroy the rock to release the tenth Sprite Bulb.

The final Sprite Bulb location is just one section over to the left from where the previous one one, along the upper wall right when you enter the next clearing.

What Are Sprite Bulbs Used For In Mario and Luigi: Brothership

After progressing a bit further into the game, you'll unlock Battle Plugs, which are crafted using Sprite Bulbs . Battle Plugs range greatly from passive boosts, like accessories, to active abilities to use in battle. Battle Plugs offer some of the best boosts or abilities, with later, stronger ones requiring players to craft weaker ones first. To use some of the best Battle Plugs in the game, you'll need to craft a lot meaning you'll need a lot of Sprite Bulbs, so it's best to start collecting early.

item.title: Black Ops 6 Zombies: How to Farm Salvage
item.description:
Crafting is back in Black Ops 6 Zombies , and so is Salvage. Players are going to need a ton of the latter if they want to improve their odds of survival, but getting tons of Salvage is much easier said than done, especially since the game doesn't tell players how to get it.

Farming large quantities of Salvage may seem like a pain, but there are a number of ways to reduce the overall grind. Even the best weapons for BO6 Zombies need to get upgraded, and to do that, you'll need to get a lot Salvage before the undead horde becomes too much to handle. Here's how you can do so.

Best Ways To Get Salvage In Black Ops 6 Zombies

The simplest way to boost your Salvage gains per run is to aim for the head. Critical Kills on zombies have a higher chance of dropping Salvage for players , and since headshots deal more damage than bodyshots, there's no reason not to aim for the noggin when you have a train of undead going.

To boost your Salvage drops even more, equip a suppressor on your starting weapon. You can setup your Zombies builds in BO6 prior to starting a match, and if you aren't planning on doing a purist pistol start run, slap a silencer onto your gun (assuming you have the attachment unlocked). The drop rate boost for Salvage is noticeable, and with suppressed headshot kills, players should be able to upgrade their weapon to purple rarity on or before Wave 15.

You can farm account and weapon XP in BO6 Zombies. If you don't feel like hopping into a multiplayer game, pick any weapon you want and grind away in any of the Zombies maps.

Map Specific Secrets

There are plenty of secrets littered in Black Ops 6 Zombies maps, and some of them may give players some Salvage and other rewards for finding them. For example, the blood pool in the Liberty Falls map will give you a bunch of Salvage if you throw three Semtex grenades into it . You can also smack the snacks vending machine near the blood pool for some free Salvage too.

Rampage Inducers

If you don't want to deal with the slow early game in every Zombies match, you can interact with Rampage Inducers to ramp up the difficulty. This won't necessarily increase Salvage drops, but it will increase enemy spawn rates (on top of making them move faster). Having a Rampage Inducer toggled on means you'll be able to fight more things earlier on into a match, giving you more opportunities to earn Salvage.

Rampage Inducers can be deactivated, so if you feel like things are getting too hot, you can always go back to it and turn it off.
